00010 extern char data[];  // defined by kernel.ld
00011 pde_t *kpgdir;  // for use in scheduler()
00012 struct segdesc gdt[NSEGS];

00014 // Set up CPU's kernel segment descriptors.
00015 // Run once on entry on each CPU.
00016 void
00017 seginit(void)
00018 {
00019   struct cpu *c;
00020 
00021   // Map "logical" addresses to virtual addresses using identity map.
00022   // Cannot share a CODE descriptor for both kernel and user
00023   // because it would have to have DPL_USR, but the CPU forbids
00024   // an interrupt from CPL=0 to DPL=3.
00025   c = &cpus[cpunum()];
00026   c->gdt[SEG_KCODE] = SEG(STA_X|STA_R, 0, 0xffffffff, 0);
00027   c->gdt[SEG_KDATA] = SEG(STA_W, 0, 0xffffffff, 0);
00028   c->gdt[SEG_UCODE] = SEG(STA_X|STA_R, 0, 0xffffffff, DPL_USER);
00029   c->gdt[SEG_UDATA] = SEG(STA_W, 0, 0xffffffff, DPL_USER);
00030 
00031   // Map cpu, and curproc
00032   c->gdt[SEG_KCPU] = SEG(STA_W, &c->cpu, 8, 0);
00033 
00034   lgdt(c->gdt, sizeof(c->gdt));
00035   loadgs(SEG_KCPU << 3);
00036   
00037   // Initialize cpu-local storage.
00038   cpu = c;
00039   proc = 0;
00040 }
00041 
00042 // Return the address of the PTE in page table pgdir
00043 // that corresponds to virtual address va.  If alloc!=0,
00044 // create any required page table pages.
00045 static pte_t *
00046 walkpgdir(pde_t *pgdir, const void *va, int alloc)
00047 {
00048   pde_t *pde;
00049   pte_t *pgtab;
00050 
00051   pde = &pgdir[PDX(va)];
00052   if(*pde & PTE_P){
00053     pgtab = (pte_t*)p2v(PTE_ADDR(*pde));
00054   } else {
00055     if(!alloc || (pgtab = (pte_t*)kalloc()) == 0)
00056       return 0;
00057     // Make sure all those PTE_P bits are zero.
00058     memset(pgtab, 0, PGSIZE);
00059     // The permissions here are overly generous, but they can
00060     // be further restricted by the permissions in the page table 
00061     // entries, if necessary.
00062     *pde = v2p(pgtab) | PTE_P | PTE_W | PTE_U;
00063   }
00064   return &pgtab[PTX(va)];
00065 }
00066 
00067 // Create PTEs for virtual addresses starting at va that refer to
00068 // physical addresses starting at pa. va and size might not
00069 // be page-aligned.
00070 static int
00071 mappages(pde_t *pgdir, void *va, uint size, uint pa, int perm)
00072 {
00073   char *a, *last;
00074   pte_t *pte;
00075   
00076   a = (char*)PGROUNDDOWN((uint)va);
00077   last = (char*)PGROUNDDOWN(((uint)va) + size - 1);
00078   for(;;){
00079     if((pte = walkpgdir(pgdir, a, 1)) == 0)
00080       return -1;
00081     if(*pte & PTE_P)
00082       panic("remap");
00083     *pte = pa | perm | PTE_P;
00084     if(a == last)
00085       break;
00086     a += PGSIZE;
00087     pa += PGSIZE;
00088   }
00089   return 0;
00090 }
00091 
00092 // There is one page table per process, plus one that's used when
00093 // a CPU is not running any process (kpgdir). The kernel uses the
00094 // current process's page table during system calls and interrupts;
00095 // page protection bits prevent user code from using the kernel's
00096 // mappings.
00097 // 
00098 // setupkvm() and exec() set up every page table like this:
00099 //
00100 //   0..KERNBASE: user memory (text+data+stack+heap), mapped to
00101 //                phys memory allocated by the kernel
00102 //   KERNBASE..KERNBASE+EXTMEM: mapped to 0..EXTMEM (for I/O space)
00103 //   KERNBASE+EXTMEM..data: mapped to EXTMEM..V2P(data)
00104 //                for the kernel's instructions and r/o data
00105 //   data..KERNBASE+PHYSTOP: mapped to V2P(data)..PHYSTOP, 
00106 //                                  rw data + free physical memory
00107 //   0xfe000000..0: mapped direct (devices such as ioapic)
00108 //
00109 // The kernel allocates physical memory for its heap and for user memory
00110 // between V2P(end) and the end of physical memory (PHYSTOP)
00111 // (directly addressable from end..P2V(PHYSTOP)).
00112 
00113 // This table defines the kernel's mappings, which are present in
00114 // every process's page table.
00115 static struct kmap {
00116   void *virt;
00117   uint phys_start;
00118   uint phys_end;
00119   int perm;
00120 } kmap[] = {
00121   { (void*) KERNBASE, 0,             EXTMEM,    PTE_W},  // I/O space
00122   { (void*) KERNLINK, V2P(KERNLINK), V2P(data), 0}, // kernel text+rodata
00123   { (void*) data,     V2P(data),     PHYSTOP,   PTE_W},  // kernel data, memory
00124   { (void*) DEVSPACE, DEVSPACE,      0,         PTE_W},  // more devices
00125 };
00126 
00127 // Set up kernel part of a page table.
00128 pde_t*
00129 setupkvm()
00130 {
00131   pde_t *pgdir;
00132   struct kmap *k;
00133 
00134   if((pgdir = (pde_t*)kalloc()) == 0)
00135     return 0;
00136   memset(pgdir, 0, PGSIZE);
00137   if (p2v(PHYSTOP) > (void*)DEVSPACE)
00138     panic("PHYSTOP too high");
00139   for(k = kmap; k < &kmap[NELEM(kmap)]; k++)
00140     if(mappages(pgdir, k->virt, k->phys_end - k->phys_start, 
00141                 (uint)k->phys_start, k->perm) < 0)
00142       return 0;
00143   return pgdir;
00144 }
00145 
00146 // Allocate one page table for the machine for the kernel address
00147 // space for scheduler processes.
00148 void
00149 kvmalloc(void)
00150 {
00151   kpgdir = setupkvm();
00152   switchkvm();
00153 }
00154 
00155 // Switch h/w page table register to the kernel-only page table,
00156 // for when no process is running.
00157 void
00158 switchkvm(void)
00159 {
00160   lcr3(v2p(kpgdir));   // switch to the kernel page table
00161 }
00162 
00163 // Switch TSS and h/w page table to correspond to process p.
00164 void
00165 switchuvm(struct proc *p)
00166 {
00167   pushcli();
00168   cpu->gdt[SEG_TSS] = SEG16(STS_T32A, &cpu->ts, sizeof(cpu->ts)-1, 0);
00169   cpu->gdt[SEG_TSS].s = 0;
00170   cpu->ts.ss0 = SEG_KDATA << 3;
00171   cpu->ts.esp0 = (uint)proc->kstack + KSTACKSIZE;
00172   ltr(SEG_TSS << 3);
00173   if(p->pgdir == 0)
00174     panic("switchuvm: no pgdir");
00175   lcr3(v2p(p->pgdir));  // switch to new address space
00176   popcli();
00177 }
00178 
00179 // Load the initcode into address 0 of pgdir.
00180 // sz must be less than a page.
00181 void
00182 inituvm(pde_t *pgdir, char *init, uint sz)
00183 {
00184   char *mem;
00185   
00186   if(sz >= PGSIZE)
00187     panic("inituvm: more than a page");
00188   mem = kalloc();
00189   memset(mem, 0, PGSIZE);
00190   mappages(pgdir, 0, PGSIZE, v2p(mem), PTE_W|PTE_U);
00191   memmove(mem, init, sz);
00192 }
00193 
00194 // Load a program segment into pgdir.  addr must be page-aligned
00195 // and the pages from addr to addr+sz must already be mapped.
00196 int
00197 loaduvm(pde_t *pgdir, char *addr, struct inode *ip, uint offset, uint sz)
00198 {
00199   uint i, pa, n;
00200   pte_t *pte;
00201 
00202   if((uint) addr % PGSIZE != 0)
00203     panic("loaduvm: addr must be page aligned");
00204   for(i = 0; i < sz; i += PGSIZE){
00205     if((pte = walkpgdir(pgdir, addr+i, 0)) == 0)
00206       panic("loaduvm: address should exist");
00207     pa = PTE_ADDR(*pte);
00208     if(sz - i < PGSIZE)
00209       n = sz - i;
00210     else
00211       n = PGSIZE;
00212     if(readi(ip, p2v(pa), offset+i, n) != n)
00213       return -1;
00214   }
00215   return 0;
00216 }
00217 
00218 // Allocate page tables and physical memory to grow process from oldsz to
00219 // newsz, which need not be page aligned.  Returns new size or 0 on error.
00220 int
00221 allocuvm(pde_t *pgdir, uint oldsz, uint newsz)
00222 {
00223   char *mem;
00224   uint a;
00225 
00226   if(newsz >= KERNBASE)
00227     return 0;
00228   if(newsz < oldsz)
00229     return oldsz;
00230 
00231   a = PGROUNDUP(oldsz);
00232   for(; a < newsz; a += PGSIZE){
00233     mem = kalloc();
00234     if(mem == 0){
00235       cprintf("allocuvm out of memory\n");
00236       deallocuvm(pgdir, newsz, oldsz);
00237       return 0;
00238     }
00239     memset(mem, 0, PGSIZE);
00240     mappages(pgdir, (char*)a, PGSIZE, v2p(mem), PTE_W|PTE_U);
00241   }
00242   return newsz;
00243 }
00244 
00245 // Deallocate user pages to bring the process size from oldsz to
00246 // newsz.  oldsz and newsz need not be page-aligned, nor does newsz
00247 // need to be less than oldsz.  oldsz can be larger than the actual
00248 // process size.  Returns the new process size.
00249 int
00250 deallocuvm(pde_t *pgdir, uint oldsz, uint newsz)
00251 {
00252   pte_t *pte;
00253   uint a, pa;
00254 
00255   if(newsz >= oldsz)
00256     return oldsz;
00257 
00258   a = PGROUNDUP(newsz);
00259   for(; a  < oldsz; a += PGSIZE){
00260     pte = walkpgdir(pgdir, (char*)a, 0);
00261     if(!pte)
00262       a += (NPTENTRIES - 1) * PGSIZE;
00263     else if((*pte & PTE_P) != 0){
00264       pa = PTE_ADDR(*pte);
00265       if(pa == 0)
00266         panic("kfree");
00267       char *v = p2v(pa);
00268       kfree(v);
00269       *pte = 0;
00270     }
00271   }
00272   return newsz;
00273 }
00274 
00275 // Free a page table and all the physical memory pages
00276 // in the user part.
00277 void
00278 freevm(pde_t *pgdir)
00279 {
00280   uint i;
00281 
00282   if(pgdir == 0)
00283     panic("freevm: no pgdir");
00284   deallocuvm(pgdir, KERNBASE, 0);
00285   for(i = 0; i < NPDENTRIES; i++){
00286     if(pgdir[i] & PTE_P){
00287       char * v = p2v(PTE_ADDR(pgdir[i]));
00288       kfree(v);
00289     }
00290   }
00291   kfree((char*)pgdir);
00292 }
00293 
00294 // Clear PTE_U on a page. Used to create an inaccessible
00295 // page beneath the user stack.
00296 void
00297 clearpteu(pde_t *pgdir, char *uva)
00298 {
00299   pte_t *pte;
00300 
00301   pte = walkpgdir(pgdir, uva, 0);
00302   if(pte == 0)
00303     panic("clearpteu");
00304   *pte &= ~PTE_U;
00305 }
00306 
00307 // Given a parent process's page table, create a copy
00308 // of it for a child.
00309 pde_t*
00310 copyuvm(pde_t *pgdir, uint sz)
00311 {
00312   pde_t *d;
00313   pte_t *pte;
00314   uint pa, i;
00315   char *mem;
00316 
00317   if((d = setupkvm()) == 0)
00318     return 0;
00319   for(i = 0; i < sz; i += PGSIZE){
00320     if((pte = walkpgdir(pgdir, (void *) i, 0)) == 0)
00321       panic("copyuvm: pte should exist");
00322     if(!(*pte & PTE_P))
00323       panic("copyuvm: page not present");
00324     pa = PTE_ADDR(*pte);
00325     if((mem = kalloc()) == 0)
00326       goto bad;
00327     memmove(mem, (char*)p2v(pa), PGSIZE);
00328     if(mappages(d, (void*)i, PGSIZE, v2p(mem), PTE_W|PTE_U) < 0)
00329       goto bad;
00330   }
00331   return d;
00332 
00333 bad:
00334   freevm(d);
00335   return 0;
00336 }
00337 
00338 //PAGEBREAK!
00339 // Map user virtual address to kernel address.
00340 char*
00341 uva2ka(pde_t *pgdir, char *uva)
00342 {
00343   pte_t *pte;
00344 
00345   pte = walkpgdir(pgdir, uva, 0);
00346   if((*pte & PTE_P) == 0)
00347     return 0;
00348   if((*pte & PTE_U) == 0)
00349     return 0;
00350   return (char*)p2v(PTE_ADDR(*pte));
00351 }
00352 
00353 // Copy len bytes from p to user address va in page table pgdir.
00354 // Most useful when pgdir is not the current page table.
00355 // uva2ka ensures this only works for PTE_U pages.
00356 int
00357 copyout(pde_t *pgdir, uint va, void *p, uint len)
00358 {
00359   char *buf, *pa0;
00360   uint n, va0;
00361 
00362   buf = (char*)p;
00363   while(len > 0){
00364     va0 = (uint)PGROUNDDOWN(va);
00365     pa0 = uva2ka(pgdir, (char*)va0);
00366     if(pa0 == 0)
00367       return -1;
00368     n = PGSIZE - (va - va0);
00369     if(n > len)
00370       n = len;
00371     memmove(pa0 + (va - va0), buf, n);
00372     len -= n;
00373     buf += n;
00374     va = va0 + PGSIZE;
00375   }
00376   return 0;
00377 }
